Week prepared a statistical report on existing conditions of

AISES SPIRITS

Hawaiian Luau,Moonlight Ride,
Senior Prom,Banquet Planned
Ralph Flanagan and his Orchestra will highlight the timehonored Hopkins Senior Prom to
be held at the Southern Hotel on
June 9.
The prom itself is just one of
many events which crowd June
Week and include a Moonlight
Boat Ride, a Hawaiian Luau at
Camp Bel-Air, the traditional
Senior Banquet, and, of course.
Commencement.
Band Includes Trio, Quintet
The Flanagan Orchestra features its rhythm section with .
Ralph Flanagan himself on the
piano. In addition to the orchestra, the band breaks up into
the Flanagan Trio and Flanagan's Flatbush Five.
To date the Flanagan Orchestra which records for Imperial
Records has been voted America's top band in many music
popularity polls, including The
Billboard, Motion Picture Daily,
and the Cashbox Disc Jockey
Poll.
Ralph Flanagan practices for Hopkins Senior Prom

Week will be the Moonlight
Cruise on June 7 from 8:00 to 12
p.m. The cruise will last for four
hours as J.C. Higganbottom and
his All Star Jazz Band from New
York's Metropole Cafe "swing
out."

Hopkins Prexy To Address
Banquet Honoring Seniors

Payne Appointed
H.C. Chairman
For Next Year

Jim Payne, a senior, has been
chosen as next year's chairman
of the Honor Commission, retiring chairman Cleaveland Miller
announced this week.
Newly elected members include
Al Permutt, Mike Marenchie and
Charles Davis, Arts and Science
seniors; John Doud, Arts and
Science junior and Steve Engel
and Lou Svoboda, Engineering
juniors; and five sophomores:
Bob Sessions, Joe Perrotto, Felix
Hughes and Jeff Kominers from
the school of Arts and Sciences
and Bruce Williams from the
school of Engineering.

Prankster Blockade Detours Police Car
A group of Hopkins pranksters perplexed quite a number
of Charles Street motorists including a Baltimore Police paddy
wagon last Saturday night when
they erected a blockade across
the service road directing drivers
to take a "detour" up the bowl
and onto the Hopkins campus.
The blockade, constructed of
a couple of "no parking" horses
and a detour sign on a post,
succeeded in diverting many
drivers around the bowl for
more than a half hour. At'about
12:20 a police paddy wagon
drove up, hesitated, and then
fell for the prank by driving
up the bowl, Circling around
,the bowl to the point where
he started, the policeman at the
wheel realized what was going
Mysterious detour sign foils motorists, police, and passing llama On and promptly threw all the

paraphanalia into a heap on
the side of the road.
This reporter sensed that something was in the air when walking past Homewood House at
11:15 that evening. At that time
there was a suspicious group
of students lurking in the environs of the bowl and Homewood House. Returning a short
while later with the News-Letter
photographer,
this
reporter
found the aforementioned blockade and quite a few very confused drivers.

Honor
In a trial held May 20 by
the Honor Commission a
sophomore engineering student was acquited of a violation of the Honor System.

Tickets Now On Sale
Tickets for June Week are
on sale in front of the student
shop from 12-1 p.m. and in the
dormitory cafeteria from 5-6
p.m. Strip tickets for the whole
week are $15.00 for undergraduates and $13.00 for seniors. Individual tickets are $5.50 for the
Moonlight Cruise, $6.00 for the
Senior Prom, and $7.00 for the
Luau.

Orientation Week
Provides Change
From Last Year
A reception and campus tour
on Friday, September 23 for both
in-town and out-of-town students and parents followed by an
evening meal at Levering will
open next year's Orientation
Week, according to Dave Adams,
Chairman.
This procedure will eliminate
the sensitive situation of past
years when in-town students
were politely requested to deave
Shriver Hall following Dr. Milton
Eisenhower's talk while the outof-town students were invited to
a dormitory reception.
The much criticized organization assembly has been ,eliminated. Students will be informed
of their group assignments advisers, and rooms of their advisers by means of a group list
distributed to them as they leave
Shriver Hall following Dr. Eisenhower's talk. Copies will also be
posted in the dormitory,

to advising. Course changes will

Water,Fire, Morrill

hour and a half, involved 150 students at its peak. It started
after 1 a.m. with several waterfights and a lot of noisemaking.

quadrangle to see what was

The Johns Hopkins Hack
Chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon, national
honorary
journalism
fraternity, reported the recent
election-appointment of officers
for 1960-61.
They are as follows: President
and Great Grand Momo, W.
Harry Lambright; Vice-President
and Lesser Grand Momo, George
Powell; Secretary - Treasurer
and Least Grand Momo, Gerry
Spanier.
The new slate of officers, proposed by '59-60 Momos Handmaker, Kopelman and Sundermeyer and approved by Handmaker, Kopelman and Sundermeyer, will begin their terms of
office at the annual arboreal
seminar of the chapter on June
8.
The officers-elect, who immediately called a summit meeting to insure a vigorous program
of inactivity for the coming year,
announced that "we hope to follow in the footsteps of tradition."
The annual Pi Delta Epsilon

About nine hundred Fulbright
scholarships for graduate study
or pre-doctoral research in 30
different countries will be available for the 1961-62 academic
year.
In addition, scholarships for
study in Latin America under
the Inter-American Cultural Convention are also offered for
1961-62.
Applications for both the Fulbright and IACC Awards will be
accepted until November 1, 1960.
Requests for applications must
be postmarked before October 15.
The Fulbright scholarships
cover travel, tuition, books, and
maintenance for one academic
year. Countries participating in
the program include Australia,
Austria, Belgium and Luxembourg, Brazil, Chile, Republic of
China, Colombia, Denmark, Ecuador, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, India,
Iran, Italy, Japan, Netherlands,
New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan,
Peru, Philippines, Spain, Sweden,
Turkey, Thailand, the United
Kingdom, and the United Arab

Republic. Similar awards for
study in Ireland are available.
The IACC program makes one
or more awards available for
graduate study in the following
Latin American countries: Bolivia, Brazil, Chile Colombia,
Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican
Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala,
Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Peru,
and Venezuela.

were Wilson Fewster and
Keith Spalding.

Today I conclude my sixth year of writing columns for the
makers of Marlboro and Philip Morris cigarettes. It has been
my custom during these six years to make no attempt to be
funny in this final column. (I have achieved this objective
many times during the year also, but never on purpose.) The
reasons for the lack of levity in this final column are two: first,
you are preparing for final exams and, short of holding you
down and tickling you, there is no way in the world to make you
laugh at this time; and, second, for many of us this is a leavetaking, and leave-takings, I think, ought not be flippant.
If I have brought you a moment or two of cheer during the
past year, I ,am rewarded. If I have persuaded you to try
Marlboro or Philip Morris cigarettes, you are rewarded.
Let me pause here to express my heartfelt gratitude to the
makers of Marlboro and Philip Morris. They have given me
complete freedom in the writing of these columns. There has
not been the slightest hint of censorship. They have never
changed so much as one comma in my copy. I wish to take this
occasion to state publicly that I am forever grateful to these
enlightened tobacconists and I hereby serve notice that if they
find it in their- corporate heart to engage me for another year
of columning, I shall require a substantial increase in salary.
The money is not what matters—not as money, that is, but
only as a token. I want to be assured that they love me as
much as I love Marlboro and Philip Morris. And what, indeed,
is not to love? Marlboro is a cigarette which- proves beyond
cavil that flavor did not go out when filters came in. Philip
Morris is a cigarette that is pure mildness from lip-end to tipend. Both of these estimable smokes come in soft-pack or
flip-top box. Neither is ever sold in bulk.

The summer lies ahead. For underclassmen summer will be
a hiatus, a breather in which to restore yourselves for next
year's resumption of busy college life. For seniors there will
be no more college. You must not,however,despair and abandon
yourself to idleness. There are other things to do in the world
besides going to school—basket weaving, for example, or building boats in bottles, or picking up tinfoil, or reading "War and
Peace." Many graduates fall into the erroneous belief that their
lives are over when they leave college. -This is not so. It is
possible to make some sort of life for yourself with a bit of
ingenuity...or, if that fails, dye your hair, change your name,
and enroll at some other college.
Whatever the future holds for you, be assured that the makers
of Marlboro and Philip Morris join me in wishing you the best
of everything. We have taken great pleasure—the makers and
I—in bringing you this column each week throughout the school
year. We hope a little pleasure has accrued to you too.
May good fortune attend your ventures. Stay happy. Stay
healthy. Stay loose.

The Johns Hopkins chapter
of Psi Chi, the national honorary psychology society, recently
elected the following members
to executive positions: Michael
Kappy, president; Bruce MCCutcheon, vice president; Pat
Bevans,
secretary;
Lester
Gurwitt, treasurer; and Donald
Irvin, historian.
Next year the group plans to
sponsor several lectures and reports on current research in
psychology, given by graduate
students, members of the Hopkins faculty, and members of
the Goucher college faculty.
Many of these colloquia will be
presented under the joint auspices of Psi Chi and the psychology club at Goucher, and
will be open to the public.

The 50th consecutive Summer
Sessions of the Johns Hopkins
University will begin on June 18
this year.
Classes will continue through
August 12 for the eight week
program, while the six week program of clas.ses will begin one
week later on June 25 and end
on August 5, one week earlier
than the regular sessions.
All day classes will be held
during the morning hours and
only a limited number of night
school classes are scheduled.
Living accommodations are
available in the dormitories;
however, no meal service will be
provided during the summer
sessions.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 27, 1960

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

Levy Named Head
Of Johns Hopkins
Alumni Associat'n
Mr. Karl M. Levy has been
elected to a two year term as
president of the Alumni Association.
Mr. Levy, a graduate of Hopkins in '26, played both varsity
football and lacrosse as an undergraduate and was captain of the
1926 lacrosse team.
After graduation Mr. Levy attended Maryland Law School
where he received an L.L.B. in
1929. Mr. Levy also played on
the Mount Washington lacrosse
team for several years and was
Captain of the team one year.
Mr. Levy is currently director
of the Century Savings and Loan
Association of Baltimore and the
Title Guarantee Company. He
has also been a member of the
executive committee of the Johns
Hopkins Alumni Association.

Hawaiian Luau,Moonlight Ride,
Senior Prom,Banquet Planned
Ralph Flanagan and his Orchestra will highlight the timehonored Hopkins Senior Prom to
be held at the Southern Hotel on
June 9.
The prom itself is just one of
many events which crowd June
Week and include a Moonlight
Boat Ride, a Hawaiian Luau at
Camp Bel-Air, the traditional
Senior Banquet, and, of course.
Commencement.
Band Includes Trio, Quintet
The Flanagan Orchestra features its rhythm section with .
Ralph Flanagan himself on the
piano. In addition to the orchestra, the band breaks up into
the Flanagan Trio and Flanagan's Flatbush Five.
To date the Flanagan Orchestra which records for Imperial
Records has been voted America's top band in many music
popularity polls, including The
Billboard, Motion Picture Daily,
and the Cashbox Disc Jockey
Poll.

Payne Appointed

Jim Payne, a senior, has been
chosen as next year's chairman
of the Honor Commission, retiring chairman Cleaveland Miller
announced this week.
Newly elected members include
Al Permutt, Mike Marenchie and
Charles Davis, Arts and Science
seniors; John Doud, Arts and
Science junior and Steve Engel
and Lou Svoboda, Engineering
juniors; and five sophomores:
Bob Sessions, Joe Perrotto, Felix
Hughes and Jeff Kominers from
the school of Arts and Sciences
and Bruce Williams from the
school of Engineering.

Prankster Blockade Detours Police Car
A group of Hopkins pranksters perplexed quite a number
of Charles Street motorists including a Baltimore Police paddy
wagon last Saturday night when
they erected a blockade across
the service road directing drivers
to take a "detour" up the bowl
and onto the Hopkins campus.
The blockade, constructed of
a couple of "no parking" horses
and a detour sign on a post,
succeeded in diverting many
drivers around the bowl for
more than a half hour. At'about
12:20 a police paddy wagon
drove up, hesitated, and then
fell for the prank by driving
up the bowl, Circling around
,the bowl to the point where
he started, the policeman at the
wheel realized what was going
Mysterious detour sign foils motorists, police, and passing llama On and promptly threw all the

paraphanalia into a heap on
the side of the road.
This reporter sensed that something was in the air when walking past Homewood House at
11:15 that evening. At that time
there was a suspicious group
of students lurking in the environs of the bowl and Homewood House. Returning a short
while later with the News-Letter
photographer,
this
reporter
found the aforementioned blockade and quite a few very confused drivers.

Honor
In a trial held May 20 by
the Honor Commission a
sophomore engineering student was acquited of a violation of the Honor System.

Tickets Now On Sale
Tickets for June Week are
on sale in front of the student
shop from 12-1 p.m. and in the
dormitory cafeteria from 5-6
p.m. Strip tickets for the whole
week are $15.00 for undergraduates and $13.00 for seniors. Individual tickets are $5.50 for the
Moonlight Cruise, $6.00 for the
Senior Prom, and $7.00 for the
Luau.

Orientation Week
Provides Change
From Last Year
A reception and campus tour
on Friday, September 23 for both
in-town and out-of-town students and parents followed by an
evening meal at Levering will
open next year's Orientation
Week, according to Dave Adams,
Chairman.
This procedure will eliminate
the sensitive situation of past
years when in-town students
were politely requested to deave
Shriver Hall following Dr. Milton
Eisenhower's talk while the outof-town students were invited to
a dormitory reception.
The much criticized organization assembly has been ,eliminated. Students will be informed
of their group assignments advisers, and rooms of their advisers by means of a group list
distributed to them as they leave
Shriver Hall following Dr. Eisenhower's talk. Copies will also be
posted in the dormitory,

The Johns Hopkins Hack
Chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon, national
honorary
journalism
fraternity, reported the recent
election-appointment of officers
for 1960-61.
They are as follows: President
and Great Grand Momo, W.
Harry Lambright; Vice-President
and Lesser Grand Momo, George
Powell; Secretary - Treasurer
and Least Grand Momo, Gerry
Spanier.
The new slate of officers, proposed by '59-60 Momos Handmaker, Kopelman and Sundermeyer and approved by Handmaker, Kopelman and Sundermeyer, will begin their terms of
office at the annual arboreal
seminar of the chapter on June
8.
The officers-elect, who immediately called a summit meeting to insure a vigorous program
of inactivity for the coming year,
announced that "we hope to follow in the footsteps of tradition."

About nine hundred Fulbright
scholarships for graduate study
or pre-doctoral research in 30
different countries will be available for the 1961-62 academic
year.
In addition, scholarships for
study in Latin America under
the Inter-American Cultural Convention are also offered for
1961-62.
Applications for both the Fulbright and IACC Awards will be
accepted until November 1, 1960.
Requests for applications must
be postmarked before October 15.
The Fulbright scholarships
cover travel, tuition, books, and
maintenance for one academic
year. Countries participating in
the program include Australia,
Austria, Belgium and Luxembourg, Brazil, Chile, Republic of
China, Colombia, Denmark, Ecuador, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, India,
Iran, Italy, Japan, Netherlands,
New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan,
Peru, Philippines, Spain, Sweden,
Turkey, Thailand, the United
Kingdom, and the United Arab

Republic. Similar awards for
study in Ireland are available.
The IACC program makes one
or more awards available for
graduate study in the following
Latin American countries: Bolivia, Brazil, Chile Colombia,
Costa Rica, Cuba, the Dominican
Republic, Ecuador, Guatemala,
Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Paraguay, Peru,
and Venezuela.

(Author of "I Was a Teen-age Dtvarf","The Many
Loves of Dobie Gillis", etc.)

Today I conclude my sixth year of writing columns for the
makers of Marlboro and Philip Morris cigarettes. It has been
my custom during these six years to make no attempt to be
funny in this final column. (I have achieved this objective
many times during the year also, but never on purpose.) The
reasons for the lack of levity in this final column are two: first,
you are preparing for final exams and, short of holding you
down and tickling you, there is no way in the world to make you
laugh at this time; and, second, for many of us this is a leavetaking, and leave-takings, I think, ought not be flippant.
If I have brought you a moment or two of cheer during the
past year, I ,am rewarded. If I have persuaded you to try
Marlboro or Philip Morris cigarettes, you are rewarded.
Let me pause here to express my heartfelt gratitude to the
makers of Marlboro and Philip Morris. They have given me
complete freedom in the writing of these columns. There has
not been the slightest hint of censorship. They have never
changed so much as one comma in my copy. I wish to take this
occasion to state publicly that I am forever grateful to these
enlightened tobacconists and I hereby serve notice that if they
find it in their- corporate heart to engage me for another year
of columning, I shall require a substantial increase in salary.
The money is not what matters—not as money, that is, but
only as a token. I want to be assured that they love me as
much as I love Marlboro and Philip Morris. And what, indeed,
is not to love? Marlboro is a cigarette which- proves beyond
cavil that flavor did not go out when filters came in. Philip
Morris is a cigarette that is pure mildness from lip-end to tipend. Both of these estimable smokes come in soft-pack or
flip-top box. Neither is ever sold in bulk.

The summer lies ahead. For underclassmen summer will be
a hiatus, a breather in which to restore yourselves for next
year's resumption of busy college life. For seniors there will
be no more college. You must not,however,despair and abandon
yourself to idleness. There are other things to do in the world
besides going to school—basket weaving, for example, or building boats in bottles, or picking up tinfoil, or reading "War and
Peace." Many graduates fall into the erroneous belief that their
lives are over when they leave college. -This is not so. It is
possible to make some sort of life for yourself with a bit of
ingenuity...or, if that fails, dye your hair, change your name,
and enroll at some other college.
Whatever the future holds for you, be assured that the makers
of Marlboro and Philip Morris join me in wishing you the best
of everything. We have taken great pleasure—the makers and
I—in bringing you this column each week throughout the school

The Johns Hopkins chapter
of Psi Chi, the national honorary psychology society, recently
elected the following members
to executive positions: Michael
Kappy, president; Bruce MCCutcheon, vice president; Pat
Bevans,
secretary;
Lester
Gurwitt, treasurer; and Donald
Irvin, historian.
Next year the group plans to
sponsor several lectures and reports on current research in
psychology, given by graduate
students, members of the Hopkins faculty, and members of
the Goucher college faculty.
Many of these colloquia will be
presented under the joint auspices of Psi Chi and the psychology club at Goucher, and
will be open to the public.

The 50th consecutive Summer
Sessions of the Johns Hopkins
University will begin on June 18
this year.
Classes will continue through
August 12 for the eight week
program, while the six week program of clas.ses will begin one
week later on June 25 and end
on August 5, one week earlier
than the regular sessions.
All day classes will be held

school classes are scheduled.
Living accommodations are
available in the dormitories;
however, no meal service will be

sessions.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 27, 1960

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE EIGHT

Levy Named Head
Of Johns Hopkins
Alumni Associat'n
Mr. Karl M. Levy has been
elected to a two year term as
president of the Alumni Association.
Mr. Levy, a graduate of Hopkins in '26, played both varsity
football and lacrosse as an undergraduate and was captain of the
1926 lacrosse team.
After graduation Mr. Levy attended Maryland Law School
where he received an L.L.B. in
1929. Mr. Levy also played on
the Mount Washington lacrosse
team for several years and was
Captain of the team one year.
Mr. Levy is currently director
of the Century Savings and Loan
Association of Baltimore and the
Title Guarantee Company. He
has also been a member of the
executive committee of the Johns
Hopkins Alumni Association.
